block.p: Glass and More Glass UrbanGlass, 647 Fulton Street, at Rockwell Place, Brooklyn; (718) 625-3685, ext. 0.

UrbanGlass is the host of the 30th annual conference of the Glass Art Society, which will be held today through Saturday. Tickets for the closing party and an auction of glass artworks at the GaleGates Art Center, 37 Main Street in Brooklyn, are $50. Reservations are required.

Other events include an exhibition of marbles at the gallery at Grand Army Plaza, Flatbush Avenue off Union Street, on Saturday and Sunday, from 1 to 5 p.m. There will also be a marble festival on Sunday, with displays and an effort to set the record for the world's biggest marble game, at Flatbush Avenue near Grand Army Plaza.

Tomorrow, from 5 to 8 p.m., galleries and nonprofit organizations in Manhattan and Brooklyn will be open to visitors. They include UrbanGlass, the Elsa Mott Ives Gallery at the Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue at 53rd Street, and Heller Gallery, 420 West 14th Street. No charge.
By Women for Women Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue, near 15th Street; (212) 651-9359.

Crafts made by women from around the world, including silver jewelry, beaded bracelets and embroidered children's linens, will be for sale on Tuesday, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Part of the proceeds will benefit Count Me In, a nonprofit organization offering loans to women entrepreneurs. No charge for admission.
In Eloise's Shoes Pulitzer Fountain in front of the Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue at 59th Street; (212) 535-2526.

The Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts will offer a tour for children at the Plaza Hotel, which was home to Eloise, the children's book character. The tour for ages 5 to 8 is on Saturday, from 10 a.m. to noon. Reservations are required. Fee, $10; children, $5.
Rose Enthusiasts Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street; (516) 759-1435.
Michael Ruggiero, the senior curator of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden at the New York Botanical Garden, will speak at a meeting of the Manhattan Rose Society on Wednesday at 6:30 p.m. No charge.
Fashion Views Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology, Seventh Avenue at 27th Street; (212) 217-5800.

''Louise Dahl-Wolfe, The American Image,'' an exhibition of more than 130 prints by the fashion photographer, who shot 86 covers for Harper's Bazaar magazine, starts Tuesday and runs through Aug. 12. The images will be shown with memorabilia, letters and personal photographs by Dahl-Wolfe (1895-1989), who took pictures of Mae West, Eudora Welty and Josephine Baker, among others. Open Tuesday through Friday, noon to 8 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. No charge.
Backyard Gardens Hofstra Arboretum at Hofstra University; (516) 463-6815.

In the first of two self-guided tours to benefit the arboretum, 12 private gardens will be open in Massapequa, N.Y., on June 17, from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. The tour will offer ideas for typical backyard spaces.
The second tour, on Aug. 19 from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m., will feature water gardens with waterfalls, koi ponds and cantilevered pools.
Reservations are required. Fee, each tour, $50; members and those 62 and older, $40.
East End Gardens Cullman Garden, Prospect Street, off Bay Street, Sag Harbor; (631) 267-3000.

The hillside garden, which features terraces, stone walls and flowering shrubs, will be open for a self-guided tour with two others on the East End on Saturday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Tickets, to benefit East Hampton Business Alliance, $20.
A Walk in Orange County Family Business, Union Street and Route 17K, Montgomery, N.Y.; (914) 457-3457.

Eight houses and their gardens will be open for a self-guided tour on Sunday, from 1 to 5 p.m. The sites include a 1790 Greek Revival style farmhouse and a 1753 house overlooking the Wallkill River, which has marble fireplaces and its original baking oven. Tickets, to benefit Citizens for Montgomery, $10.
